# [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

## Introduction

The archetypical nounal sentence is governed by an abstract foundational government that governs
a subject and its info, both in the u-state.

For example:

(@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans} . 

In example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun)
above, an abstract foundational government governs the subject
[زَيْد]{.ar}
and
its info
[قَائِم]{.ar}
both in the u-state.

[إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters
are a set of six foundational government particles
that take an archetypical nounal sentence as their input and
transform it, by governing
the subject in the u-state and the info in the u-state.
Furthermore, each particle has its own meaning that it imparts to the input sentence.

When the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} or its sisters is a pronoun,

(This is discussed in more detail in section\ (ref) below.)
For example:

(@) [إِنَّكَ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed you are standing.]{.trans} . 
-->


The set of
[إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters
is:

  i. [إِنَّ]{.ar} [indeed]{.trans}
 ii. [أَنَّ]{.ar} [that]{.trans}
iii. [كَأَنَّ]{.ar} [as if]{.trans}
 iv. [لَـٰكِنَّ]{.ar} [but]{.trans}
  v. [لَيْتَ]{.ar} [would that]{.trans}
 vi. [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} [perhaps]{.trans}

We will discuss them in the following sections.

## [إِنَّ]{.ar} [inna]{.trn}

<!--
(@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans}
-->

### Basic meaning of [إِنَّ]{.ar}

[إِنَّ]{.ar} has an assertive meaning.
It asserts the property which its info expresses about its subject.
For example:

<!--
For example, the particle [إِنَّ]{.ar} can take 
example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
as input and transform it into:
-->

(@inna_zaydan_qaaimun) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans} . 

As you can see,
the foundational government particle [إِنَّ]{.ar}
has transformed the input example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun)
by governing the subject
[زَيْد]{.ar} in the a-state
and
its info
[قَائِم]{.ar} in the u-state.
It has also added the assertive meaning "[indeed]{.trans}".


<!--
[إِنَّ]{.ar} is also a means for a sentence to begin with an indefinite subject
(after [إِنَّ]{.ar} itself, of course).
For example:
-->

### [إِنَّ]{.ar} with a pronoun subject

When the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} (or any of its sisters) is a pronoun,
then the attached pronouns are used.
So we will say, for example:

(@) [إنه قائم وإنها جالسة و إنكما قائمان وإنهم جالسون]{.ar}

When the subject is a pronoun for the singular speaker-participant [ي]{.ar},
then a guarding-[ن]{.ar} may optionally be inserted.
So we can say either
[إِنَّنِي]{.ar} or [إِنِّي]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [إني/إنني قائم]{.ar}

And when 
the subject is a pronoun for the plural speaker-participant [نَا]{.ar},
then the two [ن]{.ar}s can optionally be combined.
So we can say either
[إِنَّنَا]{.ar} or [إِنَّا]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [إنا/إننا قائمون]{.ar}

The above rules, which allow adding or dropping a [ن]{.ar},
are common for all of the sisters of [إِنَّ]{.ar} that end with [ن]{.ar}:
So we can say:

* [إِنَّنِي]{.ar} or [إِنِّي]{.ar} and [إِنَّنَا]{.ar} or [إِنَّا]{.ar}.
* [أَنَّنِي]{.ar} or [أَنِّي]{.ar} and [أَنَّنَا]{.ar} or [أَنَّا]{.ar}.
* [كَأَنَّنِي]{.ar} or [كَأَنِّي]{.ar} and [كَأَنَّنَا]{.ar} or [كَأَنَّا]{.ar}.
* [لَـٰكِنَّنِي]{.ar} or [لَـٰكِنِّي]{.ar} and [لَـٰكِنَّنَا]{.ar} or [لَـٰكِنَّا]{.ar}.

[لَيْتَ]{.ar} and [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} have modified rules, which will be covered in their respective sections, if Allāh wills.

### An [إِنَّ]{.ar} as part of a larger sentence

An [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence can itself,
be a part of a larger sentence.
For example:

(@) [زَيْدٌ إِنَّهُ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- indeed he is standing.]{.trans}  
    (The sentence [إِنَّهُ قَائِمٌ]{.ar} is the info of the subject [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.)

We will explore this more in section\ (inna vs anna) below).

## [أَنَّ]{.ar} [anna]{.trn}

### Interpretation of the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a [maSdar]{.trn2} construction

[أَنَّ]{.ar} may be translated as "[that]{.trans}".
[أَنَّ]{.ar} is unique amongst
[إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters
that when it transforms an input nounal sentence
the output is actually not a structurally complete sentence anymore.
Here is its output after transforming example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun):

(@anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [that Zayd is standing]{.trans}

As you can see above,
example (@anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
does not stand by itself as a complete sentence.
Terminologically,
[زَيْدًا]{.ar}
is the subject of [أَنَّ]{.ar}
and 
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar} is
its info.
But once [أَنَّ]{.ar} has been added to the sentence, then the resulting output actually
only constitutes a single element of a sentence
(in terms of sentence structure).
Let's explain what we mean
by making example (@anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
a part of a larger sentence:

<!--
In order to make example () structutally complete
it has to be part of a larger sentence.
So for example, we could say:
-->

(@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [That Zayd is standing pleases me.]{.trans}

Now the sentence is structurally complete.
In this sentence,
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
(i.e. [أَنَّ]{.ar}, its subject, and its info together)
constitutes the structure-starter element of the sentence
as the doer of the verb
[يُعْجِبُنِي]{.ar}.
The verb
[يُعْجِبُنِي]{.ar}
is the structure-completer of the sentence.

The grammarians have theorized that 
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
is able to constitute a single sentence element
because it is interpreted
as a
[maSdar]{.trn2} construction.
And the [maSdar]{.trn2} is then able to take the place of a single element of the sentence.
In example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
the [maSdar]{.trn2} is interpreted as follows:

(@) [أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar} = [قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
    [that Zayd is standing]{.trans} = [Zayd's [being] standing]{.trans}

<!--
the [maSdar]{.trn2} interpretation of
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
[أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
is theorized as
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
[Zayd's standing(ness)]{.trans}.
-->

If we replace 
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
in example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
with this interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} construction,
we get:

(@) [يُعْجِبُنِي قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd's [being] standing pleases me.]{.trans}.

Now we can see how
the interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} construction
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
constitutes the structure-starter of the sentence.
(Technically,
the annexe noun
[قِيَامُ]{.ar} is the structure-starter and
[زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
is it its base noun governee,
but loosely speaking they can be considered one unit.)

<!--
Because of this interpretation of
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
as a 
[maSdar]{.trn2} construction,
[أَنَّ]{.ar} is also known as
the _[maSdar]{.trn2}i_ [أَنَّ]{.ar}.

We have already studied in chapter\ (ref) a similar [maSdar]{.trn2}i particle:
the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}.
The [maSdar]{.trn2}i [أَنَّ]{.ar} and
the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}
are actually closely linked and we will study some aspects of
their relationship in section\ (ref) below if Allāh wills.
-->

By the way,
the interpretation of
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause
as a
[maSdar]{.trn2} construction
does not mean that
the sentence with the
[maSdar]{.trn2} construction
will have exactly the same meaning as the
sentence with [أَنَّ]{.ar}.
Rather the 
[maSdar]{.trn2} interpretation only helps us analyze the sentence grammatically.
And it will also help us determine when we can use
the [maSdar]{.trn2}i [أَنَّ]{.ar} as opposed to other alternatives.

### [أَنَّ]{.ar} clauses as different elements of a sentence

Let's get back to
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
[That Zayd is standing pleases me]{.trans}.
In this sentence,
as we just discussed,
[أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar},
because of its interpretation as
the [maSdar]{.trn2} construction
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar},
constitutes a single element, in terms of sentence structure.
In
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun),
it constitutes the doer of a verbal sentence,
which is a structural element.
But an [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause need not only constitute a doer,
or a structural element for that matter.
An [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause may constitute various elements of a sentence.
We will discuss them below:

#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a doer {.unnumbered}

We have already seen an example of
the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as the doer in
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}.
Here is another example:

(@) [بلغني أن زيدًا منطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح شيخ زاده على قواعد الإعراب]{.ar} 1/176](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/185#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[The news] that Zayd is setting out has reached me.]{.trans}

If we replace the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause with its interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} we get:

(@) [بلغني انطلاق زيدٍ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح شيخ زاده على قواعد الإعراب]{.ar} 1/176](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/185#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd's setting out has reached me.]{.trans}

#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a deputy doer {.unnumbered}

(@) [عُرِفَ أَنَّ السَّارِقَ جَرِيءٌ]{.ar}
    [[nawh_waadiH 1/264](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/256)]{.citex}  
    [That the thief is bold was known.]{.trans}  

If we replace the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause with its interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} we get:

(@) [عُرِفَ جَرَاءَةُ السَّارِقِ]{.ar}
    [[nawh_waadiH 1/264](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/256)]{.citex}  
    [The thief's boldness was known.]{.trans}  


#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a direct doee {.unnumbered}

The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause can occur in the position of a direct doee.
Here is an example:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أنّكَ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}  
    [I knew that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    
If we replace the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause with its interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} we get:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ فَضْلَكَ]{.ar}  
    [I knew your excellence.]{.trans}

    [I heard that [#eamr]{.trn2} is knowledgeable.]{.trans}

#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause in the i-state  {.unnumbered}

The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause can occur after a preposition.
For example:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ من أنّ بكرًا واقفٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح شيخ زاده على قواعد الإعراب]{.ar} 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that Zayd is stopped standing.]{.trans}  

If we replace the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause with its interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} we get:

(@) [عجبت من وقوف بكرٍ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح شيخ زاده على قواعد الإعراب]{.ar} 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at Zayd's being stopped standing.]{.trans}  

The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause can even occur as a base noun.
For example:

(@) [قَالَ أَيْنَ تُرِيدُ قَالَ أُرِيدُ أَخًا لِي فِي هَذِهِ الْقَرْيَةِ  قَالَ هَلْ لَكَ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ نِعْمَةٍ تَرُبُّهَا قَالَ لاَ **غَيْرَ أَنِّي** أَحْبَبْتُهُ فِي اللَّهِ عَزَّ وَجَلَّ]{.ar}  
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2567a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2567a)]{.citex}  
    [[He said, "Where are you intending [to go]?" He said, "I intend [to go to] a brother of mine in this town." He said, "Do you have upon him a favor that [you are seeking repayment for]?" He said, "No, **except that** I have loved him [for the sake of] Allāh the Exalted and Glorious."]{.trans}  

#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a info {.unnumbered}

(@) [أمرك أنك ذاهب]{.ar}
    [[[الجنى الداني]{.ar} 409](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/391#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Your state-of-affairs is that you are going.]{.trans}  
    (The interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} [ذَهَابُكَ]{.ar} is the info.)

#### The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a subject {.unnumbered}

The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause as a subject is not as common as the other categories,
and has some restrictions.
Generally, it won't begin the sentence.
Instead, its info will usually precede it.^[See [[الجنى الداني]{.ar} 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1) for an exception. See also [[شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 1/204 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11742/195) for another example.]
For example:

(@) [في ظني أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[[الجنى الداني]{.ar} 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[It is] in my estimation that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    ([في ظني]{.ar} is analyzed as a fronted info and the interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} construction
    [فَضْلُكَ]{.ar} [your excellence]{.trans} is the backed subject.)

(@) [وَمِنۡ ءَایَـٰتِهِۦۤ أَنَّكَ تَرَى ٱلۡأَرۡضَ خَـٰشِعَةࣰ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة فصلت]{.ar} 41:39](https://quran.com/41/39)]{.citex}^[See [[إعراب القرآن للدعاس]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/iraab-daas/41/39) for [سورة فصلت]{.ar} 41:39 and [[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/206 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/573).]  
    [And of His signs is that you see the earth stilled]{.trans}


(@) [أحقا أنك ذاهب]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/205](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/572)]{.citex}  
    [[Is it] really that you are going?]{.trans}  
    (The interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} [ذَهَابُكَ]{.ar} is the subject.
    [حَقًّا]{.ar} is analyzed as an adverb info.^[See [[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/206 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/573).])

The [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause may even be an subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and [كَانَ]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [كان في ظني أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[[الجنى الداني]{.ar} 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[It] was in my estimation that you are excellent.]{.trans}  

As the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar}, the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause must be separated from [إِنَّ]{.ar}:

(@) [إن عندي أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[[الجنى الداني]{.ar} 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [it is your rank] with me that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    i.e. [You are excellent in my sight.]{.trans}

When the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause is a governee of [كَانَ]{.ar} then it can, in general, be either the subject or the info.
For example:

(@) [فَكَانَ عَـٰقِبَتَهُمَاۤ أَنَّهُمَا فِی ٱلنَّارِ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة الحشر]{.ar} 59:17](https://quran.com/59/17)]{.citex}  
    [So the outcome for both of them is that they will be in the Fire]{.trans}  
    ([عَاقِبَة]{.ar} is in the u-state in some recitations.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/59/17) for [سورة الحشر]{.ar} 59:17; [[معاني القرآن وإعرابه للزجاج]{.ar} 5/149](https://shamela.ws/book/922/1939); [[معاني القرآن للفراء]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/farraa/7/5) for [سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:5]

Compare also to section\ (masdar an in kaana chapter).

### The interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} when the info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is a prepositional/adverbial phrase

Consider the following sentences,
where the info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is a prepositional or adverbial phrase:

(@) [عجبتُ من أن زيداً عندك]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 24/10](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/419)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that Zayd is at [your place].]{.trans}  
    (The info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is an adverbial phrase: [عِنْدَكَ]{.ar} [at your place]{.trans}.)

(@) [عجبت من أن زيداً في الدار]{.ar}

-->

    [I knew that Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  
    (The info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is an adverbial phrase: [فِي الدَّارِ]{.ar} [in the house]{.trans}.)


In such cases, the interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} is general beingness, represented by the [maSdar]{.trn2}
[كَوْن]{.ar}
or
[اسْتِقْرَار]{.ar},
as

    [[haazimi 24/10](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/419)]{.citex}

(@) [علمت كون زيد في الدار]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's being in the house.]{.trans}  

### The interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} when the info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is a substantive

Consider the following sentence,
where the info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is a substantive:


(@) [علمت أن زيداً أسد]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that Zayd is a lion.]{.trans}  
    (The info of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is a substantive noun: [أَسَدٌ]{.ar} [a lion]{.trans}.)

In this case as well, the interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} can be general beingness:

(@) [علمت كون زيد أسداً]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's being a lion.]{.trans}  

Or the interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} can be formed from the substantive, using the suffix
[ـِيَّة]{.ar} [-iyyah]{.trn}
(see section\ (ref)),
as below:

(@) [علمت أسدية زيد]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's lion-like-ness.]{.trans}  

### Optionally delete the preposition before [أَنَّ]{.ar}

When the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause is in the i-state following a preposition,
then it is allowed to (optionally) delete the preposition, for the same meaning,
as long as the meaning remains clear.
So, instead of saying:

(@) [عجبت **من** أنك قائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 2/151](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/538)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that you are standing.]{.trans}  

 we can say:

(@) [عجبت أنك قائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 2/151](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/538)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered that you are standing.]{.trans}

### [لِأَنَّ]{.ar} [because]{.trans}

The preposition [لِ]{.ar} when attached before [أَنَّ]{.ar} can signify the meaning
[because]{.trans}.^[Wright 1/293B]
For example:

(@) [قَالَ كَانَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم إِذَا أُتِيَ بِطَعَامٍ أَكَلَ مِنْهُ وَبَعَثَ بِفَضْلِهِ إِلَىَّ وَإِنَّهُ بَعَثَ إِلَىَّ يَوْمًا بِفَضْلَةٍ لَمْ يَأْكُلْ مِنْهَا **لأَنَّ** فِيهَا ثُومًا فَسَأَلْتُهُ أَحَرَامٌ هُوَ قَالَ لاَ وَلَكِنِّي أَكْرَهُهُ مِنْ أَجْلِ رِيحِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2053](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2053)]{.citex}  
    [He said, "The Messenger of Allāh [ﷺ]{.aralt} would, when he was brought some food, eat from it and send its extra to me. And indeed he sent to me, one day, some extra having not eaten from it **because** in it was some garlic. So I asked him, 'Is it unlawful?' He said, 'No, but I dislike it because of its odor.'"]{.trans}

### [أَنَّ]{.ar} with the meaning of [لَعَلَّ]{.ar}

As a niche use,
[أَنَّ]{.ar} can be used with the meaning of [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} (see section\ (ref) below).
For example:

(@) [ائتِ السوقَ أنكَ تشتري لَنَا شيئا]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 5/178](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/1561)]{.citex}  
    [Come to the market [so] that you may buy for us something.]{.trans}  

(@) [ما أدري أنه صاحبها]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 5/178](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/1561)]{.citex}  
    [I don't know, perhaps he is his companion.]{.trans}  


## [كَأَنَّ]{.ar} [kaEanna]{.trn}

[كَأَنَّ]{.ar} signifies [as if]{.trans}.
Examples:

(@) [كَأَنَّ الْعِلْمَ نُورٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/272]{.citex}  
    [[It is] as if knowledge is a light.]{.trans}  

(@) [كَأَنَّ عَلِيًّا أَسَدٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/272]{.citex}  
    [[It is] as if [#ealiyy]{.trn2} is a lion.]{.trans}  

(@) [ فَجِيءَ بِنَا كَأَنَّا أَفْرُخٌ]{.ar}
    [[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :4192](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:4192)]{.citex}  
    [So we were brought [and it was] as if we [were] chicks.]{.trans}  

(@) [كَأَنَّهُمۡ حُمُرࣱ مُّسۡتَنفِرَةࣱ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة المدثر]{.ar} 74:50](https://quran.com/74/50)]{.citex}  
    [As if they were alarmed donkeys]{.trans}

(@) [كَأَنِّي أَنْظُرُ إِلَى بَيَاضِهِ فِي يَدِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :65](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:65)]{.citex}  
    [It is as if I am looking at its whiteness in his hand.]{.trans}  

## [لَـٰكِنَّ]{.ar} [lAkinna]{.trn}

[لَـٰكِنَّ]{.ar} signifies [but]{.trans}.
It forms a complete sentence with its subject and its info.
But it will usually follow a previous sentence and contrast it.
Examples:

(@) [الشَّمْسُ مُشْرِقَةٌ لَكِنَّ الْجَوَّ بَارِدٌ]{.ar}  
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/272]{.citex}  
    [The sun is bright but the air is cold.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَالَ یَـٰقَوۡمِ لَیۡسَ بِی ضَلَـٰلَةࣱ وَلَـٰكِنِّی رَسُولࣱ مِّن رَّبِّ ٱلۡعَـٰلَمِینَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:61](https://quran.com/7/61)]{.citex}  
    [[Noah] said, "O my people, there is not error in me, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds."]{.trans}  

## [لَيْتَ]{.ar} [layta]{.trn}

[لَيْتَ]{.ar} has a wishful meaning.
For example:

(@) [ليت زيداً قائمًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/568](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1932)]{.citex}  
    [Would that Zayd were standing.]{.trans}  

The vocative [يَا]{.ar}
is frequently used before
[لَيْتَ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [قَالَ يَـٰلَيْتَ قَوْمِى يَعْلَمُونَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة يس]{.ar} 36:26](https://quran.com/36/26)]{.citex}  
    [He said, "I wish my people could know"]{.trans}

When the subject is a pronoun for the singular speaker-participant [ي]{.ar},
then a guarding-[ن]{.ar} is inserted by default, thus:
[لَيْتَنِي]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [وَيَقُولُ ٱلْكَافِرُ يَـٰلَيْتَنِى كُنتُ تُرَٰبًۢا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة النبأ]{.ar} 78:40](https://quran.com/78/40)]{.citex}  
    [and the disbeliever will say, "Oh, I wish that I were dust!"]{.trans}  

Very rarely, the guarding-[ن]{.ar} can be omitted thus: [لَيْتِي]{.ar}.^[[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 1/332](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/332#p1)]


When 
the subject is a pronoun for the plural speaker-participant [نَا]{.ar},
then the [ن]{.ar} of the pronoun is never omitted, and we will say:
[لَيْتَنَا]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [يَـٰلَيْتَنَآ أَطَعْنَا ٱللَّهَ وَأَطَعْنَا ٱلرَّسُولَا۠]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأحزاب]{.ar} 33:66](https://quran.com/33/66)]{.citex}  
    [How we wish we had obeyed Allāh and obeyed the Messenger.]{.trans}  
    
[أَنَّ]{.ar} can be  combined with [لَيْتَ]{.ar} thus:

(@) [**ليت أنّ** زيدًا خارجٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/569](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1933#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Would that Zayd were going out.]{.trans}  

(@) [لَيْتَ أَنَّهُ شَاعِرٌ]{.ar}
    [Fischer 180]{.citex}  
    [Would that he were a poet.]{.trans}

## [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} [laealla]{.trn}

[لَعَلَّ]{.ar} signifies [perhaps]{.trans}.
It tends to be used in situations signifying hope for, or apprehension from, an impending event.^[[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/569](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1933#p1)]

Example of hope:

(@) [لعل زيدا يكرمني]{.ar}
    [[[معاني النحو]{.ar} 1/305](https://shamela.ws/book/17801/304)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps (i.e. I hope) Zayd will honor me.]{.trans}

Example of apprehension:

(@) [لعلّ بكرًا يضرب]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/570](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1934#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps (i.e. I fear) Bakr will beat.]{.trans}  

Opposite to [لَيْتَ]{.ar},
when the subject is a pronoun for the singular speaker-participant [ي]{.ar},
then a guarding-[ن]{.ar} is not inserted by default, thus:
[لَعَلِّي]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [إِذْ رَءَا نَارًۭا فَقَالَ لِأَهْلِهِ ٱمْكُثُوٓا۟ إِنِّىٓ ءَانَسْتُ نَارًۭا **لَّعَلِّىٓ** ءَاتِيكُم مِّنْهَا بِقَبَسٍ أَوْ أَجِدُ عَلَى ٱلنَّارِ هُدًۭى]{.quran}
    [[[سورة طه]{.ar} 20:10](https://quran.com/20/10)]{.citex}  
    [When he saw a fire and said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I can bring you a torch or find at the fire some guidance."]{.trans}  

Very rarely, a guarding-[ن]{.ar} can be added thus: [لَعَلَّنِي]{.ar}.^[[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 1/333](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/333#p1)]

But like [لَيْتَ]{.ar},
the subject is a pronoun for the plural speaker-participant [نَا]{.ar},
then the [ن]{.ar} of the pronoun is not never omitted, and we will say:
[لَعَلَّنَا]{.ar}.
For example:


(@) [أَخْبِرْ صَاحِبَكَ أَنَّا قَدْ جِئْنَا **وَلَعَلَّنَا** سَنَعُودُ إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :4359](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:4359)]{.citex}  
    [Inform your companion that we came and perhaps we will come again, if Allāh wills.]{.trans}  

Here are some more examples showing the semantic range of [لَعَلَّ]{.ar}:

(@) [**لَعَلَّكُمْ** لَوْ لَمْ تَفْعَلُوا كَانَ خَيْرًا]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2362](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2362)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps if you did not do [it], it would be better.]{.trans}  


(@) [إِنَّكُمْ لاَ تَدْرُونَ **لَعَلَّكُمْ** أَنْ تُبْتَلَوْا]{.ar}
    [[[سنن ابن ماجه]{.ar} :4029](https://sunnah.com/ibnmajah:4029)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed you do not know, perhaps you will be tested.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَالَ كُنَّا عِنْدَ عُمَرَ فَقَالَ أَيُّكُمْ سَمِعَ رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم يَذْكُرُ الْفِتَنَ فَقَالَ قَوْمٌ نَحْنُ سَمِعْنَاهُ فَقَالَ **لَعَلَّكُمْ** تَعْنُونَ فِتْنَةَ الرَّجُلِ فِي أَهْلِهِ وَجَارِهِ قَالُوا أَجَلْ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :144a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:144a)]{.citex}  
    [We were with [#eumar]{.trn2} and he said, "Which of you has heard the Messenger of Allāh mention the tribulations?" Some people said, "We did hear him." So he said, "Perhaps you are meaning the tribulation of a man in regard to his household and his neighbor?"]{.trans}  

[لَعَلَّ]{.ar} can also be used for a past event.
For example:

(@) [**لَعَلَّكَ** قَبَّلْتَ أَوْ غَمَزْتَ أَوْ نَظَرْتَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :6824](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6824)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps you (only) kissed or winked or looked?]{.trans}  

(@) [**لَعَلَّنَا** أَعْجَلْنَاكَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :180](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:180)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps we have forced you to hurry?]{.trans}  

[لَعَلَّ]{.ar} is often connected in meaning to a previous sentence.
signifying in its meaning a connotation of [in order to]{.trans}.
In this sense, it approaches the meaning of [كَيْ]{.ar}.^[See (with caution) also [[الكشاف للزمخشري]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/kashaf/2/21) for [سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:21 and [[تفسير ابن عاشور]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/2/21) for [سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:21 [یَـٰۤأَیُّهَا ٱلنَّاسُ ٱعۡبُدُوا۟ رَبَّكُمُ ٱلَّذِی خَلَقَكُمۡ وَٱلَّذِینَ مِن قَبۡلِكُمۡ لَعَلَّكُمۡ تَتَّقُونَ]{.quran}]
For example:

(@) [فَلَمَّا قُبِضَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فَخَرَجَ مُسَيْلِمَةُ الْكَذَّابُ قُلْتُ لأَخْرُجَنَّ إِلَى مُسَيْلِمَةَ **لَعَلِّي** أَقْتُلُهُ فَأُكَافِئَ بِهِ حَمْزَةَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :4072](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:4072)]{.citex}  
    [When the Messenger of Allāh [ﷺ]{.aralt} passed away, and then Musaylimah the Liar appeared, I said, "I will surely go out to Musaylimah **so that** I may kill him and so make amends for [killing] [#Hamzah]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  

## A prepositional/adverbial phrase as the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

A prepositional/adverbial phrase can occurs as the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا فِي الدَّارِ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أَنَّ زَيْدًا عِنْدَكَ]{.ar}
    [Indeed Zayd is at [your place].]{.trans}  

In such cases,
based on what we have learned in section\ (ref),
the info is actually implicated as general beingness,
and the preposition or adverb is its governee.
But loosely speaking we may say that
the prepositional/adverbial phrase is the info.

## A complete sentence as the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

The info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters may be a complete sentence.
Examples:

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ يُعَزِّزُ صَاحِبَهُ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 272]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it makes esteemed its companion.]{.trans}  
    (The info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} is the verbal sentence [يُعَزِّزُ صَاحِبَهُ]{.ar} [it makes esteemed its companion]{.trans}.)

(@) [إِنَّ الْعَالِمَ قَدْرُهُ مُرْتَفِعٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/272]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the scholar -- his worth is high.]{.trans}  
    (The info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} is the nounal sentence [قَدْرُهُ مُرْتَفِعٌ]{.ar} [his worth is high]{.trans}.)

(@) [لَعَلَّكَ اجْتَهَدْتَ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/272]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps you may exert yourself.]{.trans}  
    (The info of [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} is the verbal sentence [اجْتَهَدْتَ]{.ar} [you exert yourself]{.trans}.)

The info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} (and its sisters) 
can even be a compound itself itself.
Here is an example where the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar}
is a [كَانَ]{.ar} sentence with its own subject and verbal sentence info:

(@) [وَإِنَّ أَبَا هُرَيْرَةَ **كَانَ يَلْزَمُ** رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم بِشِبَعِ بَطْنِهِ وَيَحْضُرُ مَا لاَ يَحْضُرُونَ وَيَحْفَظُ مَا لاَ يَحْفَظُونَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :118](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:118)]{.citex}  
    [And indeed [#abU #hurayrah]{.trn2} used to stick with the Messenger of Allāh with the fill of his stomach and be present for what they [were] not present for, and memorize what they [were] not memorizing.]{.trans}

## Word order of the subject and the info with [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

### Word order for a single element info

The subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} (and its sisters) must always follow it in word order.
And its info must always follow the subject.
So, for example,
we cannot say:

(@) ✗ [إِنَّ قَائِمٌ زَيْدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 162](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/137)]{.citex}  

We must say instead:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}

### Word order for a prepositional or adverbial phrase info

When the info is itself
(loosely speaking) the prepositional or adverbial phrase,
then then it may be placed before the subject.
Sometimes, placing the 
prepositional/adverbial phrase
before the subject is optional.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ فِي الدَّارِ ضُيُوفًا كِرَامًا]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/273]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house are noble guests.]{.trans}  

(@) [لَيْتَ عِنْدَكَ مُحَمَّدًا]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/273]{.citex}  
    [O that with you was [#muHammad]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

In such cases, where the prepositional/adverbial phrase info may be placed either before or after the subject,
the signification can be slightly diferent.
For example, if we say:

(@) [إِنَّ مَعَكَ صَاحِبَكَ.]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/80C]{.citex}  
    [Indeed, with you, is **your companion**.]{.trans}

This puts the logical accent on the subject [صَاحِبَكَ]{.ar} "your companion". If the subject is placed first then this puts the logical accent on the info:

(@) [إِنَّ صَاحِبَكَ مَعَكَ.]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/80C]{.citex}  
    [Indeed your companion is **with you**.]{.trans}



When the prepositional/adverbial phrase has a pronoun that refers to the subject,
then it must obligatorily be placed before the subject.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ فِي الدَّارِ سَاكِنَهَا]{.ar}
    [[[ارتشاف الضرب من لسان العرب]{.ar} 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house is its resident.]{.trans}

(@) [إِنَّ عِنْدَ هِنْدٍ بَعْلَهَا]{.ar}
    [[[ارتشاف الضرب من لسان العرب]{.ar} 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed with Hind is her husband.]{.trans}

### Word order when the info has a governee

If the info has a governee, then
the normal word order is for it to follow its governor.
For example:

(@) [إن زيدا آكل **طعامك**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

Optionally, the governee of the info can be made to precede it.
For example:

(@inna_zaydan_ta3aamaka_aakilun) [إن زيدا **طعامك** آكل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/317](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/978)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

But the governee of the info
should not, in general, precede the subject.
So we cannot say:

(@) ✗ [إن **طعامك** زيدا آكل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  

However, when the governee of the info is a prepositional or adverbial phrase,
then there is some diagreement amongst the grammarians,
with regard to whether the governee of the info can precede the subject.^[[[ارتشاف الضرب من لسان العرب]{.ar} 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244); [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/464](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/962)]
Some grammarians allowed
sentences like:

(@) [إِنَّ **عِنْدَكَ** زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed with you Zayd is sitting.]{.trans}  

(@) [إن **بك** زيدا واثق]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in you Zayd is trusting.]{.trans}  
    
Others disallowed such sentences and mandated that
the governee of the info not precede the subject
even in the case of prepositional/adverbial phrases.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]:
So they allow:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ **عِنْدَكَ**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is sitting with you.]{.trans}  

(@) [إن زيدا واثق **بك**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is trusting in you.]{.trans}  

Making the governee of the info precede it (but not the subject) is allow allowed
(as in example (@inna_zaydan_ta3aamaka_aakilun) above):

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا **عِنْدَكَ** جَالِسٌ]{.ar},

(@) [إن زيدا **بك** واثق]{.ar}

<!--
But when the info is itself
(loosely speaking) the prepositional or adverbial phrase,
then then it may be placed before the subject undisputably.
Sometimes, placing the 
prepositional/adverbial phrase
before the subject is optional.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ فِي الدَّارِ ضُيُوفًا كِرَامًا]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/273]{.citex}

## A state-of-affairs pronoun as the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

A state-of-affairs pronoun can occur as the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters.
In this case,
as usual,
the info will be a complete sentence.

As with [كَانَ]{.ar}, when the subject is a state-of-affairs pronoun,
then the info can be a nounal sentence or a verbal sentence.

For example:

(@) [**إِنَّهَا** تَكُونُ الظُّلْمَةُ وَالسَّيْلُ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :667](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:667)]{.citex}  
    [The state-of-affairs is: [there] is [at times] darkness and flooding]{.trans}  

(@) [وَقَالَ إِنَّهُ قَدِ اجْتَمَعَ لَكُمْ فِي يَوْمِكُمْ هَذَا عِيدَانِ]{.ar}  
    <https://sunnah.com/urn/504350>

## [إِنَّ]{.ar} with a [لَ]{.ar} of beginning

The _[لَ]{.ar} of beginning_ is a particle which generally occurs in the beginning of a sentence signifies an assertive meaning.
For example, if we start with:

(@) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

then we can make the sentence more assertive by using [لَ]{.ar} of beginning in its beginning:

(@) [لَزَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

The [لَ]{.ar} of beginning, in sentences without [إِنَّ]{.ar} (as above),
is placed in the beginning of the sentence
and is attached only to the subject.
If the info were fronted, we wouldn't say:

(@) ✗ [لَقَائِمٌ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/353](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1014#p1)]{.citex}  


### The [لَ]{.ar} of beginning placed before the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar}

This [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is frequently found used with [إِنَّ]{.ar}.
But instead of occurring before [إِنَّ]{.ar} thus:

(@) ✗ [لَإِنَّ]{.ar}

it is placed between the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its info, thus:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدٌ لَقَائِمٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  


When [إِنَّ]{.ar} is used together with [لَ]{.ar} of beginning as in the example above,
then the sentence signifies extra assertion,
compared to if had only [إِنَّ]{.ar} or only the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning.

In a similar manner to example () above,
we can say:

(@) [إن زيدًا لفي الدار]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  

The [لَ]{.ar} of beginning 
has certain restrictions placed on its usage,
when used with [إِنَّ]{.ar}:

Firstly, it can only be used with [إِنَّ]{.ar} and not with any of its sisters.

Secondly, the [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence should be an affirmative sentence, not a negative sentence.
So we cannot say:

(@) ✗ [إِنَّ عَلِيًّا **لَمَا** حَضَرَ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/288]{.citex}

Instead, we should say (without the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning):

(@) [إِنَّ عَلِيًّا مَا حَضَرَ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [#ealiyy]{.trn2} was not present.]{.trans}

Additionally, when the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar} is a verbal sentence with a perfect verb, then the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is not attached to the perfect verb.
But if [قَدْ]{.ar} is used before the perfect verb, then the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning may be attached before it.
So we cannot say:

(@) ✗ [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ لَرَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/288]{.citex}  

But we can say:

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ لَقَدْ رَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it has raised the worth of its companion.]{.trans}  

Or we can say without both the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning and [قَدْ]{.ar}

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ رَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it raised the worth of its companion.]{.trans}  

This restriction is not placed on a ;xabar which is a verbal sentence with a stateful verb.
So we can say:

(@) [إن زيدًا **ليخرج** اليوم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he will go out today.]{.trans}  

When the stateful verb has [سَوْفَ]{.ar},
then grammarians have disagreed with regards tp allowing [لَ]{.ar} of beginning to attach to it.^[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]

(@) [إن زيدا **لسوفَ** يقوم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he will soon stand.]{.trans}

Also, rigid perfect verbs are exempted from being restricted and may be used with [لَ]{.ar} of beginning directly.
For example:

(@) [إنّ زيدًا **لنِعْم** الرجلُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- how excellent the man.]{.trans}  

(@) [إنّ عمرًا **لِبِئْسَ** الغلامُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- how wretched the boy.]{.trans}  

However,
[لَيْسَ]{.ar} is a rigid verb, but [لَ]{.ar} of beginning does not attach to it because of the
undesirableness of two [ل]{.ar}s coming togather.
So we won't say:

(@) ✗ [إنّ زيدًا **لليس** بقائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he is not standing.]{.trans}  

When a governee of the info is placed before it in word order
(but still after the subject),
such that it comes between the subject and the info,
then [لَ]{.ar} of beginning will attach to the fronted governee, thus:

(@) [إنّ زيدًا **لَفِى الدار** قائمٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd, in the house is standing.]{.trans}  

<!--
(@) [إنك **لَعِندي** خطِي]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}
-->

(@) [إن زيدًا **لطعامَكَ** آكلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/355](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1016#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd, your food he is eating.]{.trans}  

But if the governee of the info is placed after the info then the info will have [لَ]{.ar} of beginning, not its governee.
So we won't say:

(@) ✗ [إنَّ زيدًا آكلٌ **لطعامكَ**]{.ar}
    [[[الأصول في النحو لابن السراج]{.ar} 2/235](https://shamela.ws/book/7365/739)]{.citex}  

Instead, we will say:

(@) [إنَّ زيدًا **لآكلٌ** طعامَكَ]{.ar}
    [[[الأصول في النحو لابن السراج]{.ar} 2/235](https://shamela.ws/book/7365/739)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

Also, if the subject has a attribute which occurs between it and the info,
then again [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is placed with the info.
For example:

(@) [إِنّ زيدًا الفاضِلَ **لَقَائِمٌ**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/355](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1016#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the excellent Zayd is standing]{.trans}  

### The [لَ]{.ar} of beginning placed before the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar}

So far, we have seen the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning attached before the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar}.
But,
if the info occurs before the subject in word order,
then [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is actually atached before the subject.
In this way, [لَ]{.ar} of beginning again occurs between the subject and the info.
For example:

(@) [إن في الدار **لزيدا**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/373](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/372)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house is Zayd.]{.trans}  

If the info occurs after the subject in word order,
but a governee of the info occurs before the subject,
then we have two options:
[لَ]{.ar} of beginning may optionally be attached before the subject or before the info.
For example:

(@) [إن فيها زيدًا **لقائم**]{.ar}  
    [إن فيها **لزيدًا** قائم]{.ar}  
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in it Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

### The [لَ]{.ar} of beginning with a separating-pronoun

If a separating-pronoun occurs between the subject and the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar},
and a [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is to be used, then
the [لَ]{.ar} of beginning will be attached before the separating-pronoun.
For example, if we start with:

(@) [إن زيدًا هو القائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is the standing one.]{.trans}  

and we add [لَ]{.ar} of beginning,
we get:

(@) [إن زيدًا **لَهو** القائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is the standing one.]{.trans}  


## When to use [إِنَّ]{.ar} vs [أَنَّ]{.ar}

### The basic principle

The basic principle in choosing whether to use
[إِنَّ]{.ar} vs [أَنَّ]{.ar} is:

* [إِنَّ]{.ar} is used to begin a complete sentence. As a complete sentence, it can then be a part of an larger sentence.
* [أَنَّ]{.ar} is used to begin a clause which is part of a larger sentence.
  The larger sentence,
  in order for its meaning to work,
  requires a [maSdar]{.trn2}i interpretation of the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause.

In theory, this is a pretty clear demarcation.
But in practice it can be a little tricky to tell when to use [إِنَّ]{.ar} vs [أَنَّ]{.ar}.
Let's work through some examples:

(@) [نُطْقِي اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}  
    [Wright 2/256D, [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/204, previously cited in section\ (ref)]{.citex}  
    [My utterance is "[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me."]{.trans}

In the example above,
<!--
the complete sentence
[اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}
[[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me]{.trans},
as a info,
is the structure-completer of the outer sentence,
with the subject
[نُطْقِي]{.ar}
as its structure-starter.

In such a case,
because the info is a complete sentence that stands on its own,
it can begin with [إِنَّ]{.ar} but not [أَنَّ]{.ar}.
-->
the sentence info
[اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}
[[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me]{.trans},
is simply being reported as speech.
It's not an interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2} of the info which is expressing a property about the subject
[نُطْقِي]{.ar}.
Rather, the info, as a complete sentence, is the complement of the subject.
So it can begin with [إِنَّ]{.ar} but not [أَنَّ]{.ar}, thus:
[نُطْقِي إِنَّ اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}.

Here are a couple more examples:

(@) [خَيْرُ الْقَوْلِ إِنِّي أَحْمَدُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The best of speech is: Indeed I praise.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَوْلِي إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/325](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/327#p1)]{.citex}  
    [My saying is: Indeed he is excellent.]{.trans}  

But if the info expresses a property about the subject, not as a complete sentence,
but as an interpreted [maSdar]{.trn2},
then [أَنَّ]{.ar} is used.
For example:

(@) [اعْتِقَادِي أَنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/325](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/327#p1)]{.citex}  
    [My belief is that he is excellent.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [اعْتِقَادِي فَضْلُهُ]{.ar} [My belief is his being excellent.]{.trans})

In the example above, it is not exactly the sentence
[هُوَ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
"he is excellent"
which is my belief.
Rather my belief is his _being_ excellent.

Here are some more examples of a complete sentence with [إِنَّ]{.ar} in a larger sentence.
In all the examples,
the [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence is part of the larger sentence, _as is_.
It does not need to be interpreted as a [maSdar]{.trn2} construction.

(@) [زَيْدٌ إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/324](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/326#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- indeed he is excellent.]{.trans}  

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِرَجُلٍ إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/323](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/325#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a indeed-he-is-excellent man.]{.trans}  
    (The sentence [إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar} is the attribute of [رَجُل]{.ar}.)

(@) [أَحْتَرِمُ الَّذِي إِنَّهُ مُخُلِصٌ فِي عَمَلِهِ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/275]{.citex}  
    [I respect the one who -- indeed he is sincere in his work.]{.trans}  
    (The [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence [إِنَّهُ مُخُلِصٌ فِي عَمَلِهِ]{.ar} is the connecting sentence of the connected noun [الَّذِي]{.ar}. See chapter\ (ref).)

(@) [جِئْتُ وَإِنَّ الشَّمْسَ تَغْرُبُ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/276]{.citex}  
    [I came while the sun was setting.]{.trans}  
    (The [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence [جِئْتُ وَإِنَّ الشَّمْسَ تَغْرُبُ]{.ar} is a [HAl]{.trn2}. See chapter\ (ref).)

Now let's again consider some tricky areas:

### When [إِنَّ]{.ar} or [أَنَّ]{.ar} occur as a base noun

Consider the following sentence:

(@) [اجْلِسْ حَيْثُ إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354)]{.citex}  
    [Sit where -- indeed Zayd is sitting.]{.trans}  

In the above example
[حَيْثُ]{.ar} is an adverb of place (see chapter\ (ref)) which is a annexe noun to the sentence-base noun
[إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}.
The [إِنَّ]{.ar} sentence does not require the [maSdar]{.trn2}i interpretation [جُلُوس]{.ar} for the meaning to work.

Now consider this sentence:

(@) [قَالَ كَعْبُ بْنُ مَالِكٍ لَمْ أَتَخَلَّفْ عَنْ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فِي غَزْوَةٍ غَزَاهَا قَطُّ إِلاَّ فِي غَزْوَةِ تَبُوكَ **غَيْرَ أَنِّي قَدْ تَخَلَّفْتُ** فِي غَزْوَةِ بَدْرٍ ...]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2769a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2769a)]{.citex}  
    [[#kaeb ibn #mAlik]{.trn2} said, "I didn't remain behind the Messenger of Allāh [ﷺ]{.aralt} in any expedition that he went on, ever, except in the expedition of [#tabUk]{.trn2}, other than that I remained behind in the expedition of Badr ...]{.trans}

In this example, the [أَنَّ]{.ar} clause 
[أَنِّي قَدْ تَخَلَّفْتُ]{.ar}
is base noun of [غَيْرَ]{.ar}.
[أَنَّ]{.ar} is used instead of [إِنَّ]{.ar} because, in order for the meaning to work,
the [maSdar]{.trn2} of [تَخَلَّفَ]{.ar} is interpreted, thus:
[غَيْرَ تَخَلُّفِي]{.ar}
[other than my remaining behind]{.trans}.

### In reported speech

When a sentence is reported as (direct or indirect) speech,
then [إِنَّ]{.ar} is used instead of [أَنَّ]{.ar} in the beginning of the reported speech.
(By the way, direct speech can also begin without [إِنَّ]{.ar}.)
Here are examples with [إِنَّ]{.ar}:

(@) [تُعَيّرنا أنَّا قليلٌ عَدِيدنا **فقلتُ لها إنّ** الكرام قليلُ]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1)]{.citex}  
    [She reproaches us that we -- our number is few. So I said to her, "Indeed the noble are few."]{.trans}  

(@) [**فَقِيلَ لَهَا إِنَّهُ** النَّبِيُّ صلى الله عليه وسلم]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :1283](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:1283)]{.citex}  
    [Then it was said to her Indeed he is the Prophet [ﷺ]{.aralt}]{.trans}  

In the following example, the pronoun in [إِنَّهَا]{.ar} indicates indirect speech, yet still [إِنَّ]{.ar} is used instead of [أَنَّ]{.ar}:

(@) [قَالَتْ إِنَّهَا حُبْلَى مِنَ الزِّنَا]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :1695a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:1695a)]{.citex}  
    [She said that she had become pregnant as a result of fornication.]{.trans}

The reason for using [إِنَّ]{.ar} instead of [أَنَّ]{.ar} is, again,
that that the reported speech is not interpreted as a [maSdar]{.trn2} in order to connect it to the verb [قَالَ]{.ar} before it.
Rather, the entire reported speech is, as is, the direct doee of the verb [قَالَ]{.ar}.

With other verbs that may indicate reported speech, [أَنَّ]{.ar} is typically used.
For example:

(@) [صَلَّى بِنَا سَعِيدُ بْنُ جُبَيْرٍ بِجَمْعٍ الْمَغْرِبَ ثَلاَثًا بِإِقَامَةٍ ثُمَّ سَلَّمَ ثُمَّ صَلَّى الْعِشَاءَ رَكْعَتَيْنِ ثُمَّ **ذَكَرَ أَنَّ** عَبْدَ اللَّهِ بْنَ عُمَرَ فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ **وَذَكَرَ أَنَّ** رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ]{.ar}
    [[[سنن النسائي]{.ar} :483](https://sunnah.com/nasai:483)]{.citex}  
    [Sa'eed bin Jubair led us in prayer in Jam'. (He prayed) Maghrib, three Rak'ahs with an Iqamah, then he prayed 'Isha', two Rak'ahs. Then he mentioned that 'Abdullah bin 'Umar had done that, and he mentioned that the Messenger of Allah [ﷺ]{.aralt} had done that.]{.trans}  

The reason is that now, the [maSdar]{.trn2}i meaning of the speech is interpreted as the direct doee of [ذَكَرَ]{.ar}.
That is, [he mentioned [#3abd] Allāh's **doing** that]{.trans}.

Ocassionally, we will find [أَنَّ]{.ar} used with [قَالَ]{.ar}.
And that is when [قَالَ]{.ar} is not simply reporting speech,
but signifying the speaker's belief, estimation, or claim of the _[maSdar]{.trn2}i content_ of the following speech.^[[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1); see also [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/319](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1683)]
For example:
    

(@) [أتقول المراصدُ **أن** الجو بارد فى الأسبوع المقبل]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Does the forecaster say that the weather is cold in the upcoming week?]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [Does the forecaster estimate the weather to **be** cold ...]{.trans})

### After verbs of perception

After, verbs of perception (see chapter\ (ref),
if a sentence suspends its government (see section\ (ref)),
then either [إِنَّ]{.ar} or [أَنَّ]{.ar} may be used.
For example:

(@) [علمت **إن** الرياءَ بلاءٌ]{.ar}  
    [علمت **أَن** الرياءَ بلاءٌ]{.ar}  
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/651](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/650#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that showing off is a trial.]{.trans}  

If [لَ]{.ar} of beginning is used, then, of course; it would only be used with [إِنَّ]{.ar} not [أَنَّ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [علمت **إن** الإسراف **لطريق** الفقر]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/651](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/650#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew indeed extravagance is the path to poverty.]{.trans}  

### After [إِذَا]{.ar} or suddenness

After [إِذَا]{.ar} or suddenness
(see chapter\ (ref)),
either [إِنَّ]{.ar} or [أَنَّ]{.ar} may be used^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/277; [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/356](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/355#p1). Also see editor's footnote.]:

(@) [خرجت فإذا **إن** زيدا قائم]{.ar}  
    [خرجت فإذا **أن** زيدا قائم]{.ar}  
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/356](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/355#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I came out [and] suddenly Zayd was standing.]{.trans}  

### After an oath

[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 278

[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/650

### After [ف]{.ar} in a condition-response

When the condition-response begins with a [فَ]{.ar},
either [إِنَّ]{.ar} or [أَنَّ]{.ar} (or neither) may be used.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/279]
For example:

(@) [إِنْ تَجْتَهِدْ فَإِنَّكَ/فَأَنَّكَ نَاجِحٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/279]{.citex}  
    [If you exert yourself then you will be successful.]{.trans}

[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 278
-->

## A conjunct following [إِنَّ]{.ar} and its sisters

<!--
[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 293
-->

When a noun is conjuncted to the subject of [إِنَّ]{.ar}
and the post-conjunctee is placed after the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar}
then it can optionally either be put in the a-state or the u-state.
For example:

(@) [إن زيدا قائم **وعمرا**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/375](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/374#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [إن زيدا قائم **وعمرو**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/376](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/375#p1)]{.citex}  

If the post-conjunctee is put in the u-state ([وَعَمْرٌو]{.ar}),
then it can be thought of as the
subject of a new sentence, i.e.:

(@) [إن زيدا قائم وَعَمْرٌ [كَذَلِكَ]]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/376](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/375#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing and [#eamr]{.trn2} [is like that as well].]{.trans}

When the noun that is conjuncted is put before the info of [إِنَّ]{.ar},
then according to the dominant view,
the post-conjunctee must be in the a-state.
So we will say:

(@) [إن زيدا وعمرا قائمان]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/376](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/375#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [إنك وزيدا ذاهبان]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/376](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/375#p1)]{.citex}  

Some grammarians permitted the post-conjunctee to be in the u-state in this case as well.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/376](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/375#p1)]

The rules for [أَنَّ]{.ar} and [لَـٰكِنَّ]{.ar} are the same as the rules for [إِنَّ]{.ar}.
So we will say, for example:

(@) [علمت أن زيدا قائم وعمرو/وعمرا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [علمت أن زيدا وعمرا قائمان]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [لكن عمرا منطلق وخالدا/خالد]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [لكن عمرا وخالدا منطلقان]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  


As for [كَأَنَّ]{.ar}, [لَيْتَ]{.ar}, and [لَعَلَّ]{.ar},
only the a-state is permitted for the ;,a3toof;,
whether or not it is after the info or before.
So we will say, for example:

(@) [ليت زيدا وعمرا قائمان]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [ليت زيدا قائم وعمرا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/377](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/376#p1)]{.citex}  

As mentioned, [كَأَنَّ]{.ar} and [لَعَلَّ]{.ar} are treated similarly to the above two examples.


<!--
## The lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}, [أَنْ]{.ar}, [كَأَنْ]{.ar}, and [لَـٰكِنْ]{.ar}
-->

## The lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}


[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 296

The particles
[إِنَّ]{.ar}, [أَنَّ]{.ar}, [كَأَنَّ]{.ar}, and [لَـٰكِنَّ]{.ar},
because of the [caddah]{.trn2} on the [ن]{.ar}, can be termed _heavy_.
They have
have _lightened-from-the-heavy_ versions:
[إِنْ]{.ar}, [أَنْ]{.ar}, [كَأَنْ]{.ar}, and [لَـٰكِنْ]{.ar}.
The lightened particles have somewhat different rules from their original heavy counterparts.
In this section we will treat the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}.
We will treat the rest of the lightened particles in subsequent sections, if Allāh wills.

### Governance of the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}

The lightened [إِنْ]{.ar} is less assertive in meaning than the heavy [إِنَّ]{.ar}.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/299].
In using it there are two optional possibilities:

The first, and more common, option is that the lightened leaves the state of its subject in the u-state, just like a basic nounal sentence.
But now, a [لَ]{.ar} is almost always required.
For example:

(@) [إِنْ سَعِيدٌ لَمُجْتَهِدٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/296--297]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [#saeId]{.trn2} is an exerter [of himself].]{.trans}  

Note that the subject
[سَعِيدٌ]{.ar}
is in the u-state,
and that a [لَ]{.ar} is used with the info:
[لَمُجْتَهِدٌ]{.ar}.
This [لَ]{.ar} is now called the _differentiator [لَ]{.ar}_,
because it differentiates the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}
from another type of [إِنْ]{.ar} called the _negating-[إِنْ]{.ar}_ (see chapter\ (ref)).
<!--
The negating-[إِنْ]{.ar} is used without a [لَ]{.ar} and it negates the meaning of the sentence.
For example:

(@) [إِنْ سَعِيدٌ مُجْتَهِدٌ]{.ar}  
    [**Not** is [#saeId]{.trn2} an exerter [of himself].]{.trans}  

We will treat the negating-[إِنْ]{.ar} in chapter\ (ref), if Allāh wills.

Back to the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}:
-->
Occasionally,
when the meaning is clear without it,
the differentiator [لَ]{.ar} may be omitted.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]
For example:

(@) [إِنِ الْعَاقِلُ يَتَّبِعُ سَبِيلَ الرَّشَادِ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the sensible one follows the path of right conduct.]{.trans}  

The second, and less commonly used, option is for the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar} to govern its subject in the a-state, just like the heavy [إِنَّ]{.ar}.
Now the [لَ]{.ar}
(called [لَ]{.ar} of beginning again) is optional, as it was with [إِنَّ]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [إِنْ سَعِيدًا مُجْتَهِدٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [#saeId]{.trn2} is an exerter [of himself].]{.trans}  

(@) [وَإِنَّ كُلࣰّا لَّمَّا لَیُوَفِّیَنَّهُمۡ رَبُّكَ أَعۡمَـٰلَهُمۡۚ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة هود]{.ar} 11:111](https://quran.com/11/111) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [And indeed, each [of the believers and disbelievers] - your Lord will fully compensate them for their deeds.]{.trans}  

### A verbal sentence after the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}

Unlike the heavy [إِنَّ]{.ar},
the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar} can be followed directly by a verb.
But the verb that follows it is usually constrained to be a canceling verb.
Examples:

(@) [**وَإِن كَانَتۡ** لَكَبِیرَةً إِلَّا عَلَى ٱلَّذِینَ هَدَى ٱللَّهُۗ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:143](https://quran.com/2/143) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [And indeed, it is difficult except for those whom Allāh has guided.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَالَ تَٱللَّهِ **إِن كِدتَّ** لَتُرۡدِینِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الصافات]{.ar} 37:56](https://quran.com/37/56) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [He will say, "By Allāh, you almost ruined me.]{.trans}  

(@) [**وَإِن نَّظُنُّكَ** لَمِنَ ٱلۡكَـٰذِبِینَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الشعراء]{.ar} 26:186](https://quran.com/26/186) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/297]{.citex}  
    [and indeed, we think you are among the liars.]{.trans}  

(@) [**وَإِن یَكَادُ** ٱلَّذِینَ كَفَرُوا۟ لَیُزۡلِقُونَكَ بِأَبۡصَـٰرِهِمۡ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة القلم]{.ar} 68:51](https://quran.com/68/51) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/298]{.citex}  
    [And indeed, those who disbelieve would almost make you slip with their eyes [i.e., looks]]{.trans}  

Rarely, a non-canceling verb is found to occur after the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [إِنْ قَتَلْتَ لَمُسْلِمًا]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/298, [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/382](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/381#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed you killed a Muslim]{.trans}  

The analysis of this sentence is that the subject of the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}
is implicated to be a deleted state-of-affairs pronoun.
And the verb which follows with its governees is a sentence which
is the info of the lightened [إِنْ]{.ar}.^[[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للعثيمين]{.ar} 26/6](https://shamela.ws/book/36954/256)]

## The lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}

### Governance of the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}

The lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} retains the governance of the the heavy [إِنَّ]{.ar}.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/300]
But its subject is (almost) always a deleted state-of-affairs pronoun.
And its info is then a complete sentence.
For example:

(@) [علمت أن زيد قائم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/383](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/382#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that [the state-of-affairs is:] Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

Note,
in the above example,
that [زَيدٌ]{.ar} is in the u-state because it is the subject of an independent sentence [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}.
The subject of [أَنْ]{.ar} is a deleted state-of-affairs pronoun, implicated thus: [أَنْهُ]{.ar}.

Occasionally, the subject the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} is not deleted,
in which case it won't be a state-of-affairs pronoun.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/300; [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/384](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/383#p1)]
In this case the info may either be a single noun or a complete sentence.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/385 editors footnote](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/384#p1)]

(@) [أظنُّ أنْكَ قائمٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/552](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1916#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I estimate that you are standing.]{.trans}  

(@) [أحسبُ أنْهُ ذاهبٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/552](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1916#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I deem that he is going.]{.trans}  


But most of the time,
the subject of the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} will be a deleted state-of-affairs pronoun,
and its info will be a sentence.
The sentence which is the info of this
lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}
can begin either with a noun or with a verb.

When it begins with a noun,
then it does not need any separation between it and the [أَنْ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [وَءَاخِرُ دَعۡوَىٰهُمۡ **أَنِ ٱلۡحَمۡدُ** لِلَّهِ رَبِّ ٱلۡعَـٰلَمِینَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة يونس]{.ar} 10:10](https://quran.com/10/10) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 301]{.citex}  
    [And the last of their call will be, "Praise to Allāh, Lord of the worlds!"]{.trans}  

Similarly, if the sentence info begins with a underived verb,
then again no separation is needed between it and the [أَنْ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [**وَأَن لَّیۡسَ** لِلۡإِنسَـٰنِ إِلَّا مَا سَعَىٰ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة النجم]{.ar} 53:39](https://quran.com/53/39)]{.citex}  
    [And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives]{.trans}  

(@) [أَوَلَمۡ یَنظُرُوا۟ فِی مَلَكُوتِ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَ ٰ⁠تِ وَٱلۡأَرۡضِ وَمَا خَلَقَ ٱللَّهُ مِن شَیۡءࣲ **وَأَنۡ عَسَىٰۤ** أَن یَكُونَ قَدِ ٱقۡتَرَبَ أَجَلُهُمۡۖ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:185](https://quran.com/7/185) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 301]{.citex}  
    [Do they not look into the realm of the heavens and the earth and everything that Allāh has created and [think] that perhaps their appointed time has come near?]{.trans}  

But if the verb is flexible,
then it is preferred that it be separated from
the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} by one of the following:

* [قَدْ]{.ar}.
  For example:

  (@) [قَالُوا۟ نُرِیدُ أَن نَّأۡكُلَ مِنۡهَا وَتَطۡمَىِٕنَّ قُلُوبُنَا وَنَعۡلَمَ **أَن قَدۡ** صَدَقۡتَنَا وَنَكُونَ عَلَیۡهَا مِنَ ٱلشَّـٰهِدِینَ]{.quran}
      [[[سورة المائدة]{.ar} 5:113](https://quran.com/5/113) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 301]{.citex}  
      [They said, "We wish to eat from it and let our hearts be reassured and know that you have been truthful to us and be among its witnesses."]{.trans}  


* The particles [سَ]{.ar} or [سَوْفَ]{.ar}.
  For example:

  (@) [عَلِمَ **أَن سَیَكُونُ** مِنكُم مَّرۡضَىٰ]{.quran}
      [[[سورة المزمل]{.ar} 73:20](https://quran.com/73/20) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/301]{.citex}


* One of the particle of negation [لَا]{.ar}, [لَنْ]{.ar}, or [لَمْ]{.ar}

  
  (@) [أَفَلَا یَرَوۡنَ **أَلَّا** یَرۡجِعُ إِلَیۡهِمۡ قَوۡلࣰا]{.quran}
      [[[سورة طه]{.ar} 20:89](https://quran.com/20/89) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/302]{.citex}

  (@) [أَیَحۡسَبُ **أَن لَّمۡ** یَرَهُۥۤ أَحَدٌ]{.quran}
      [[[سورة البلد]{.ar} 90:7](https://quran.com/90/7) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/302]{.citex}

  (@) [أَیَحۡسَبُ ٱلۡإِنسَـٰنُ **أَلَّن** نَّجۡمَعَ عِظَامَهُۥ]{.quran}
      [[[سورة المزمل]{.ar} 73:3](https://quran.com/73/3) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/302]{.citex}


  In non-Qurʾānic Standard Arabic,
  [أَنْ]{.ar} is not joined in writing to the following particle.
  So we will write [أَنْ لَا]{.ar}^[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 4/298], [أَنْ لَنْ]{.ar}, and [أَنْ لَمْ]{.ar}.
  But in pronunciation, the [ن]{.ar} is assimilated with the [ل]{.ar}, as usual,
  so we will say [EallA]{.trn}, [Eallan]{.trn}, and [Eallam]{.trn}, respectively.
  For example:

(@) [تَيَقَّنْتُ **أَنْ لاَ** أُسَافِرُ]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 4/298](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/2230#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I was sure that I will not journey.]{.trans}  

* The conditional particle [لَوْ]{.ar}
  For example:

  (@) [**وَأَلَّوِ** ٱسۡتَقَـٰمُوا۟ عَلَى ٱلطَّرِیقَةِ لَأَسۡقَیۡنَـٰهُم مَّاۤءً غَدَقࣰا]{.quran}
      [[[سورة الجن]{.ar} 72:16](https://quran.com/72/16) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/302]{.citex}
      
### When to use the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} vs the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}

When [أَنْ]{.ar} is to be followed by a stateful verb
(whether or not separated by a particle like [لَا]{.ar}),
then the question is should we use
the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} or the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}?

If we choose the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar},
then the stateful verb is put in the u-state.
For example:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أَنْ لاَ **يَخْرُجُ** زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/553](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1917#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that Zayd will not go out.]{.trans}

And if we choose the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar},
then the stateful verb is put in the u-state.
For example:

(@) [اشْتَهَيْتُ أَنْ لاَ **يَخْرُجَ** زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/406](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1402)]{.citex}^[The term [مخخفة]{.ar} is used by the authour here to mean [أن الخفيفة الناصبة للمضارع]{.ar} as can be seen from the statement [أفعال العلم واليقين والمعرفة وما جرى مجراها من أفعال التحقيق تختص به " أنّ " المشددة الناصبة للأسماء دون " أن " **المخففة الناصبة للأفعال**]{.ar}]  
    [I desired that Zayd not go out.]{.trans}

The general principle is that
the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} is 
used when the verb before it signifies certainty,
like [عَلِمَ]{.ar} [to know]{.trans}.
This is because it is the lightened from the heavy [أَنَّ]{.ar}, which is used assertively.

As for the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}, it is used when the verb before it signfies a wanting for something to happen,
or a fearing that something not happen.
Here are some examples that can illustrate this:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أَنْ **سَيَخْرُجُ** زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that Zayd will go out.]{.trans}

(@) [أَرْجُو أَنْ **تُحْسِنَ** إِلَيََّ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I hope that you will do good to me.]{.trans}  

(@) [أَخَافُ أَنْ **تُسِيءَ** إِلَيََّ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I fear that you will do evil to me.]{.trans}  

There are a class of verbs that vary in the amount of certainty or wanting that they signify.
Such verbs include:
[ظَنَّ]{.ar} [to conjecture]{.trans},
[حَسِبَ]{.ar} [to deem]{.trans},
[خَالَ]{.ar} [to imagine]{.trans},
[رَأَىٰ]{.ar} [to opine]{.trans},
etc.
In this context,
they can be translated in idiomatic English as [to think]{.trans}.
Furthermore, the perfect verb can be used where in Eng;ish we would use the present tense
(in accordance with what we learned in section\ (madi used for moment of utterance)).

With such verbs, both the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} (and therefore also the heavy [أَنَّ]{.ar}),
and the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar} can be used.
In theory,
the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} (and the heavy [أَنَّ]{.ar}) is used when
the speaker _believes_ the following statement to be true.^[[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/406](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1402)]

For example:

(@) [ظَنَنْتُ أَنَّكَ تَخْرُجُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that you are going out.]{.trans}  
    or [I [believe] that you will go out.]{.trans}  

(@) [ظَنَنْتُ أَنْ سَتَخْرُجُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that you will go out.]{.trans}  

(@) [حسبت أن زيدا منطلق]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/406](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1402)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that Zayd is setting out.]{.trans}  

(@) [ظننت أنك أخونا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/406](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1402)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that you are our brother.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَدْ حَسِبْتُ أَنْ لَا تَقُولُ ذَلِكَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/406](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1402)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that you will not say that.]{.trans}

(@) [أَرَىٰ أَنْ سَيَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I [believe] that he will do [it].]{.trans}

Conversely, the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar} is used when the
the speaker _feels_ the following statement, without any strong evidence or indicator which is guiding his feeling.^[[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1)]

(@) [ظننت أن تَخْرُجَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I [feel] that you will go out.]{.trans}

(@) [ظَنَنْتُ أَنْ لاَ تَفْعَلَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I [feel] that you will not do [it]]{.trans}


Despite this theoretical difference between the two uses,
practically,
the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar} is used more commonly in such situations because it is the default.^[[[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 64](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/49)]

When [أَنْ]{.ar}
is followed directly be a perfect verb
(without an intervening [قَدْ]{.ar}),
then it seems that the [أَنْ]{.ar} is a-state-izing
(despite their being no effect of the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar} on the perfect verb).
This is because the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} would have required [قَدْ]{.ar}.^[But see [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/24/9) for [سورة النور]{.ar} 24:9 for the recitation [أَنْ غَضِبَ ٱللَّهُ]{.ar} (cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 1/301). See also [[تفسير ابن عاشور]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/24/9) for [سورة النور]{.ar} 24:9 for a counter-argument.]
For example:

(@) [كرِهتُ أن قمتَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 5/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2035#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I disliked that you stood.]{.trans}  

We list the following examples to illustrate the range of [أَنْ]{.ar}.

(@) [**تَظُنُّ أَن یُفۡعَلَ بِهَا** فَاقِرَةࣱ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة القيامة]{.ar} 75:25](https://quran.com/75/25) cited by [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [فَلَا جُنَاحَ عَلَیۡهِمَاۤ أَن یَتَرَاجَعَاۤ إِن **ظَنَّاۤ أَن یُقِیمَا** حُدُودَ ٱللَّهِۗ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:230](https://quran.com/2/230) cited by [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [**وَحَسِبُوۤا۟ أَلَّا تَكُونَ** فِتۡنَةࣱ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة المائدة]{.ar} 5:71](https://quran.com/5/71) cited by [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 3/407](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/1403#p1); [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  
    [And they thought there would be no [resulting] punishment]{.trans}  
    (Some recitations have the verb following [أَنْ]{.ar} in the u-state.^[[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554 footnote 7](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)])

(@) [**أَیَحۡسَبُ أَن لَّمۡ یَرَهُۥۤ** أَحَدٌ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البلد]{.ar} 90:7](https://quran.com/90/7) cited by [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [**عَلِمَ أَن سَیَكُونُ** مِنكُم مَّرۡضَىٰ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة المزمل]{.ar} 73:20](https://quran.com/73/20) cited by [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [أَفَلَا **یَرَوۡنَ أَلَّا یَرۡجِعُ** إِلَیۡهِمۡ قَوۡلࣰا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة طه]{.ar} 20:89](https://quran.com/20/89) cited by [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/554](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1918#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [وَٱلَّذِیۤ **أَطۡمَعُ أَن یَغۡفِرَ** لِی خَطِیۤـَٔتِی یَوۡمَ ٱلدِّینِ]{.quran}

### Differentiating between the lightened an and the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}

There are four types of [أَنْ]{.ar}:

  i. the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}
 ii. the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}
iii. the explanatory [أَنْ]{.ar}
 iv. the redundant [أَنْ]{.ar}

In this section we will explain
wow can we tell when seeing a [أَنْ]{.ar},
whether it is 
a a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}, or a
lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}.
We will treat
the other two types of [أَنْ]{.ar}:
the explanatory [أَنْ]{.ar} and the redundant [أَنْ]{.ar},
in chapter\ (ref), if Allāh wills.

#### When what follows [أَنْ]{.ar} is a nounal sentence {.unnumbered}

When what follows [أَنْ]{.ar} is a nounal sentence,
and what precedes [أَنْ]{.ar} is only part of a sentence, and not a full sentence,
then the [أَنْ]{.ar} is the
lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}.
[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 4/291]
For example:

#### When what follows [أَنْ]{.ar} is a verb {.unnumbered}

When a  verb follows [أَنْ]{.ar}, then:

If is a supplication, then the [أَنْ]{.ar} is
lightened [أَنْ]{.ar}.

Otherwise

* If the [أَنْ]{.ar} is the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}, then the verb is put in the a-state.
* And if the [أَنْ]{.ar} is the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} then the verb is put in the u-state.

The following guidelines can be used to determine when to use
the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar} vs the

When the verb is a perfect verb,
then the lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} will again be used in situations involving certainty.

علمت أن قد قمت

Otherwise,
the [أَنْ]{.ar} will be the a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}

أعجبني أن قمت



The lightened [أَنْ]{.ar} is distinguished from the light a-state-izing [أَنْ]{.ar}
(which governs a stateful verb in the a-state),
with the following reasoning.

[أَنَّ]{.ar}, like [إِنَّ]{.ar} essentially signifies an assertive meaning.

<https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3600>:

::: {.ar}
والذي تقرر عند أصحابنا أن شرط عمل هذا المصدر أن يقدر بحرف مصدري والفعل، فقدر الحرف س بـ"أن" الثقيلة المسندة إلى ضمير الشأن؛ لأنه يعم أن تكون الصلة ماضية وحالاً ومستقبلة، فتقدر في الماضي: من أنه ضرب زيد عمراً، وفي المضارع: من أنه يضرب؛ لأنه يصلح للحال والاستقبال.

وقدره بعضهم بـ"أن" الناصبة للفعل؛ لأن صلتها تكون بالماضي، نحو: عجبت من أن قام زيد، وبالمضارع فتخلصه للاستقبال، نحو: عجبت من أن يقوم زيد. وبـ"ما"؛ لأنها تصلح للحال، وتوصل به، نحو: عجبت مما تضرب زيداً.
:::

<https://al-maktaba.org/book/31874/4114>
-->
